steps: We admitted we were powerless over our addiction—that our lives had become unmanageable.
Came to believe that a power within and beyond ourselves could restore us to balance.
Made a decision to align our will and our lives with the Divine as we understood it.
Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.
Admitted to the Divine, to ourselves, and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.
Were entirely ready to have the Divine remove all these defects of character.
Humbly asked the Divine to remove our shortcomings.
Made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all.
Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others.
Continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted it.
Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with the Divine as we understood it, praying for knowledge of its will for us and the power to carry that out.
Having had a spiritual awakening as a result of these steps, we tried to carry this message to others and to practice these principles in all our affairs.
Pagan_12_Steps.second_tradition: For our group purpose, there is but one ultimate authority—a loving Goddess and God as expressed in our group conscience. Our leaders are but trusted servants; they do not govern.
Pagan_12_Steps.source: Adapted from traditional 12-step programs to align with Pagan spirituality.
Pagan_12_Steps.higher_power: The Divine as understood in Pagan traditions, encompassing both immanent and transcendent aspects, guided by The Rede: 'An it harm none, do as ye will.'
